column49: Abel-François Poisson (February 18, 1727-May 10, 1781) was the brother of Jeanne-Antoinette Poisson, Marquise de Pompadour (December 29, 1721- April 15, 1764). They were the children of François Poisson (1684-June 25, 1754) and Louise-Madeleine de La Motte (1699-December 24, 1745). Abel-François about 1737 until 1754 as Monsieur Poisson de Vandières. He was appointed to succeed to the post of directeur général des bâtiments du Roi in 1745 and assumed this post upon the death of Charles-François-Paul Lenormant de Tournehem on november 19, 1751. In September 1754, Louis XV raised the estate at Marigny-en-Orxois into a marquisate, ennobling Abel-François and entitling him Marquis de Marigny. After his retirement from office in 1773, Marigny spent his time and money improving the gardens and buildings at his Loire valley château Menars which he had inherited from Madame de Pompadour. Louis XVI granted him the title Marquis de Menars in 1778. Marigny, as he was known during his career and to history, married Marie-Françoise-Constance-Julie Filleul on December 28, 1766. They had two children, both of whom died in infancy. Marigny died suddenly and intestate on May 10, 1781 at his Parisian residence, the hôtel de Menars (Massiac) on the Place des Victoires. The liquidation of the estate gave rise to five major sales, four within a few years of his death and one one-hundred years later of the sculpture from his garden at Menars: 1. Paris, hôtel de Menars, March 18- April 6, 1782 (Lugt 3376 and 3389. Sale originally announced for February); 2. Paris, Sale of the Library of the marquis de Marigny et de Menars, April, 1782; 3. Bercy, maison de Pâté-Bercy (country house of Marigny in the suburbs of Paris), 4 May, 1785 (Lugt 3876); 4. Paris, 8 February, 1787, Sale of Drawings and Pierres Gravées from the Collection the Marquis de Marigny et de Menars, (Lugt 4137); 5. Menars, 10 June, 1881, Menars le Château near Blois, Sale of the Sculpture from the Parc de Menars, (Lugt 41195).]

Il est donc possible qu'une telle publicité ait permis la dispersion rapide d'un certain nombre d'oeuvres laissées à sa mort par Pierre II Mignard. Si tel est le cas, l'Etat imprimé de 1733 ne représente plus qu'une partie - celle des invendus - des tableaux lui ayant appartenu. Boyer writes also Ceux-ci [les dessins] semblent exclus [...] de l'Etat de 1733 et ces desseins originaux pourraient bien faire partie des oeuvres qui furent alors dispersées. Mais cette dénomination pourrait aussi recouvrir, non pas des dessins au sens actuel du terme, mais plutôt les esquisses peintes que l'Etat de 1733 range, quant à lui, sous le nom d'Etudes.
